{{refimprove|date=February 2014}} [[File:Supine and prone 2012-02-20.jpg|thumb|Supine position and [[prone position]]]] The '''supine position''' ({{IPAc-en|s|ə|ˈ|p|aɪ|n}} or {{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|uː|p|aɪ|n}}) means lying horizontally with the face and torso facing up, as opposed to the [[prone position]], which is face down. When used in surgical procedures, it allows access to the [[peritoneal]], [[thoracic]] and [[pericardium|pericardial]] regions; as well as the head, neck and extremities.<ref>Rothrock, J. C. (2007) ''Alexander's Care of the Patient in Surgery 13th Ed.'' Mobsy Elsevier: St Louis, Missouri. p. 148.</ref>
Using [[anatomical terms of location]], the dorsal side is down, and the ventral side is up, when supine. [[Image:Supine.jpg|thumb|A man lying in the supine position]]
== Semi-supine == In scientific literature "semi-supine" commonly refers to positions where the upper body is tilted (at 45° or variations) and not completely horizontal.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=16869446 |year=2006 |last1=Petropoulou |first1=E |last2=Lancellotti |first2=P |last3=Piérard |first3=LA |title=Quantitative analysis of semi-supine exercise echocardiography--influence of age on myocardial Doppler imaging indices |volume=61 |issue=3 |pages=271–7 |journal=Acta Cardiologica |doi=10.2143/ac.61.3.2014827}}</ref>
== Relation to sudden infant death syndrome == {{main|Sudden infant death syndrome}} The decline in death due to sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is said to be attributable to having babies sleep in the supine position.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Marcarelli|first1=Rebekah|title=Sudden Infant Death Syndrome Could Be Prevented By Making Sure Baby Sleeps On Back|url=http://www.hngn.com/articles/30403/20140503/sudden-infant-death-syndrome-could-be-prevented-by-making-sure-infant-sleeps-on-back.htm|website=hngn.com|publisher=Headlines & Global News|accessdate=25 March 2016|date=3 May 2014}}</ref> It is believed that in the prone position babies are more at risk to re-breathe their own [[carbon dioxide]]. Because of the immature state of their [[central chemoreceptors]], infants do not respond to the subsequent [[respiratory acidosis]] that develops.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=L'Hoir MP, Engelberts AC, van Well GT, McClelland S, Westers P, Dandachli T, Mellenbergh GJ, Wolters WH, Huber J | title = Risk and preventive factors for cot death in The Netherlands, a low-incidence country | journal = Eur. J. Pediatr. | volume = 157 | issue = 8 | pages = 681–8 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9727856 | doi = 10.1007/s004310050911 }}</ref><ref name="aap_sacks">{{cite web |title=The Changing Concept of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome: Diagnostic Coding Shifts, Controversies Regarding the Sleeping Environment, and New Variables to Consider in Reducing Risk |publisher=[[American Academy of Pediatrics]] |accessdate=2008-11-06 |url=http://aappolicy.aappublications.org/cgi/content/full/pediatrics;116/5/1245#SEC15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203234922/http://aappolicy.aappublications.org/cgi/content/full/pediatrics%3B116/5/1245#SEC15 |archivedate=2008-12-03 |df= }}</ref>
== Obstructive sleep apnea == [[Obstructive sleep apnea]] (OSA) is a form of [[sleep apnea]] that occurs more frequently and is most severe when individuals are sleeping in the supine position. Studies and evidence show that OSA related to sleeping in the supine position is related to the [[Airway management|airway positioning]], reduced [[lung volume]], and the inability of [[airway]] muscles to dilate enough to compensate as the airway collapses.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Joosten|first=Simon A.|last2=O'Driscoll|first2=Denise M.|last3=Berger|first3=Philip J.|last4=Hamilton|first4=Garun S.|date=2014-02-01|title=Supine position related obstructive sleep apnea in adults: pathogenesis and treatment|journal=Sleep Medicine Reviews|volume=18|issue=1|pages=7–17|doi=10.1016/j.smrv.2013.01.005|issn=1532-2955|pmid=23669094}}</ref> With individuals who have OSA, many [[health care providers]] encourage their [[patients]] to avoid the supine position while asleep and sleep [[Lateral (anatomy)|laterally]] or sleep with the head of their bed up in a 30 or 45 degree angle.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tuomilehto|first=Henri|last2=Seppä|first2=Juha|last3=Partinen|first3=Markku|last4=Uusitupa|first4=Matti|date=2009-07-01|title=Avoiding the Supine Posture during Sleep for Patients with Mild Obstructive Sleep Apnea|url=http://www.atsjournals.org/doi/full/10.1164/ajrccm.180.1.101a|journal=American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine|volume=180|issue=1|pages=101–102|doi=10.1164/ajrccm.180.1.101a|issn=1073-449X}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Anatomical position]] * [[Lying (position)|Lying position]] * [[Prone position]] * [[Sleep paralysis]]

Siva Kumar]] |illustrator = |cover_artist = |country = [[India]] |language = English |series = |subject = Art |genre = |publisher = Mapin Publishing |pub_date = November 16, 2011 |english_pub_date = |pages = 240 |isbn = 8189995618 |oclc = |preceded_by = |followed_by = }} '''''The Last Harvest: Paintings of Rabindranath Tagore''''' is a book on [[Rabindranath Tagore]] (1861–1941) and his paintings edited by [[R. Siva Kumar]]. In 2011 it was produced in conjunction with the traveling exhibition ''[[The Last Harvest: Paintings of Rabindranath Tagore]]''.
==Exhibition== {{main|The Last Harvest: Paintings of Rabindranath Tagore}} The book was produced in conjunction with the traveling exhibition of Rabindranath Tagore's paintings as part of India's National Commemoration of the 150th Birth Anniversary of Rabindranath Tagore, organised by [[India]]'s [[Ministry of Culture (India)|Ministry of Culture]].
==Contents== * Rabindranath Tagore – A Biographical Sketch * Rabindranath Tagore's [[Santiniketan]] – Where Life and Art Meet * Rabindranath Tagore's First Ever Exhibition in Paris * Rabindranath Tagore's Paintings in German * [[Stella Kramrisch]] and the [[Bauhaus]] in [[Calcutta]] * Tagore's Sense of Rhythm * Rabindrasangeet – Rabindranath Tagore's Musical Legacy * Engagement with Modernity – Paintings of Rabindranath Tagore in the [[National Gallery of Modern Art]], [[Delhi]]
==Contributors== The book was edited by [[R. Siva Kumar]], with contributions by France Bhattacharya, Uma Das Gupta, Martin Kampchen, Lars-Christian Koch, Rajeev Lochan, Kris K. Manjapra, Kathleen O'Connell and [[William Radice]].<ref>[http://www.mapinpub.in/bookinfo.php?title=The_Last_Harvest The Last Harvest] at Mapin Publishing</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Rabindra Chitravali]]'' – a 2011 publication in 4 volumes on Tagore's paintings, edited by [[R. Siva Kumar]]

'''Toehold mediated strand displacement (TMSD)''' is an enzyme-free molecular tool to exchange one strand of [[DNA]] or [[RNA]] (output) with another strand (input). It is based on the hybridization of two complementary strands of DNA or RNA via Watson-Crick base pairing (A-T/U and C-G) and makes use of a process called [[branch migration]] <ref name=Yurke2000 >{{cite journal |last1=Yurke |first1=Bernard |title=A DNA-fuelled molecular machine made of DNA |journal=Nature |date=2000 |volume=406 |issue=6796 |page=605}}</ref>. Although [[branch migration]] has been known to the scientific community since the 1970s, TMSD has not been introduced to the field of DNA nanotechnology until 2000 when Yurke et al. was the first who took advantage of TMSD <ref name=Yurke2000 /><ref name=Guo2017>{{cite journal |last1=Guo |first1=Yijun |last2=Wei |first2=Bing |last3=Xiao |first3=Shiyan |last4=Yao |first4=Dongbao |last5=Li |first5=Hui |last6=Xu |first6=Huaguo |last7=Song |first7=Tingjie |last8=Li |first8=Xiang |last9=Liang |first9=Haojun |title=Recent advances in molecular machines based on toehold-mediated strand displacement reaction |journal=Quantitative Biology |date=2017 |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=25-41}}</ref>. He used the technique to open and close a set of DNA tweezers made of two DNA helices using an auxiliary strand of DNA as fuel <ref name=Yurke2000 /><ref name=DavidYu2011 />. Since its first use, the technique has been modified for the construction of autonomous molecular motors, catalytic amplifiers, reprogrammable DNA nanostructures and [[Molecular logic gate|molecular logic gates]] <ref name=DavidYu2011>{{cite journal |last1=Zhang |first1=David Yu |last2=Seelig |first2=Georg |title=Dynamic DNA nanotechnology using strand-displacement reactions |journal=Nature Chemistry |date=2011 |volume=3 |issue=2 |page=103}}</ref><ref name=DavidYu2009>{{cite journal |last1=Zhang |first1=David Yu |last2=Winfree |first2=Erik |title=Control of DNA strand displacement kinetics using toehold exchange |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |date=2009 |volume=131 |issue=47 |pages=17303–17314}}</ref>. It has also been used in conjunction with RNA for the production of kinetically-controlled ribosensors <ref name="Burke2018">{{cite web |last1=Burke |first1=Cassandra R |last2=Sparkman- Yager |first2=David |last3=Carothers |first3=James M |title=Multi-state design of kinetically-controlled RNA aptamer ribosensors |url=https://www.biorxiv.org/content/biorxiv/early/2017/11/03/213538.full.pdf |website=bioRxiv |publisher=bioRxiv |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>. TMSD starts with a double-stranded DNA complex composed of the original strand and the protector strand <ref name=Guo2017 />. The original strand has an overhanging region the so-called “toehold” which is complementary to a third strand of DNA referred to as the “invading strand”. The invading strand is a sequence of [[single-stranded DNA]] (ssDNA) which is complementary to the original strand <ref name=DavidYu2011 /><ref name=Guo2017 />. The toehold regions initiate the process of TMSD by allowing the complementary invading strand to hybridize with the original strand, creating a DNA complex composed of three strands of DNA <ref name=DavidYu2011 /><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Yurke |first1=Bernard |last2=Millis |first2=Allen P |title=Using DNA to power nanostructures |journal=Genetic Programming and Evolvable Machines |date=2003 |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=111–122}}</ref>. This initial endothermic step is rate limiting <ref name=Yurke2000 /> and can be tuned by varying the strength (length and sequence composition e.g. G-C or A-T rich strands) of the toehold region <ref name=DavidYu2011 />. The ability to tune the rate of strand displacement over a range of 6 orders of magnitude generates the backbone of this technique and allows the kinetic control of DNA or RNA devices <ref name=DavidYu2009 />. After the binding of the invading strand and the original strand occurred, [[branch migration]] of the invading domain then allows the displacement of the initial hybridized strand (protector strand) <ref name=Yurke2000 />. The protector strand can possess its own unique toehold and can, therefore, turn into an invading strand itself, starting a [[DNA nanotechnology#Strand displacement cascades|strand-displacement cascade]] <ref name=Guo2017 /><ref name=DavidYu2009 /><ref name="Zhang2007">{{cite journal |last1=Zhang |first1=David Yu |title=Engineering entropy-driven reactions and networks catalyzed by DNA |journal=Science |date=2007 |volume=318 |issue=5853 |pages=1121–1125}}</ref>. The whole process is energetically favored and although a reverse reaction can occur its rate is up to 6 orders of magnitude slower <ref name=DavidYu2009 />. Additional control over the system of toehold mediated strand displacement can be introduced by toehold sequestering <ref name=DavidYu2009 />.
== Toehold sequestering == Toehold sequestering is a technique to “mask” the toehold region, rendering its accessibility.<ref name=DavidYu2009 /><ref name=DavidYu2011 />. There are several ways to do so but the most common approaches are hybridizing the toehold with a complementary strand <ref name="Zhang2007" /> or by designing the toehold region to form a [[Stem-loop|hairpin loop]] <ref>{{cite journal |last1=Green |first1=Simon J |last2=Lubrich |first2=Daniel |last3=Turberfield |first3=Andrew J |title=DNA hairpins: fuel for autonomous DNA devices |journal=Biophysical Journal |date=2006 |volume=91 |issue=8 |pages=2966–2975}}</ref>. Masking and unmasking of the toehold domains together with the ability to precisely control the kinetics of the reaction makes toehold mediated strand displacement a valuable tool in the field of [[DNA nanotechnology|DNA nanotechnology ]]<ref name=DavidYu2009 />.
